meta.title: Other mood stabilizers for bipolar disorder

content:
Introduction

Valproate, carbamazepine, and lamotrigine are anticonvulsants used in the treatment of bipolar disorder due to their mood-stabilizing effects.  Each of these drugs has unique pharmacologic properties, clinical indications, and safety profiles.  Lithium and antipsychotics, which are also treatments for bipolar disorder, are discussed in separate articles.

Valproate

Indications



Valproate is used in bipolar disorder to treat acute mania, either as monotherapy or in combination with an antipsychotic.  It can be used for maintenance treatment to prevent further mood episodes.  Valproate is also used to treat seizures and migraines.

Pharmacology



Valproate, also known as valproic acid (valproate's protonated form), has several mechanisms of action that contribute to its wide range of therapeutic effects, including seizure control and mood stabilization (

):



  • Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, reducing neuronal excitation (
    figure 1
    )
  • Blocks gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) transaminase, increasing the availability and inhibitory effects of GABA
  • Inhibits histone deacetylase, increasing DNA transcription of genes that have downstream effects on neuroplasticity (eg, upregulation of brain-derived neurotrophic factor)


Valproate has a rapid onset of action, with peak concentrations occurring 4-5 hours after being taken.  In acute mania, response can typically be seen within 1-4 days of achieving therapeutic serum levels (eg, 50-125 mcg/mL).



Valproate is highly protein-bound (

figure 2
); unbound valproate crosses the blood-brain barrier for its pharmacologic effects.  In states of hypoalbuminemia (eg, malnutrition), elevated levels of unbound valproate are found relative to the given dose, resulting in a greater risk of toxicity even at therapeutic doses.

Drug-drug interactions



  • Valproate inhibits lamotrigine clearance, increasing serum lamotrigine levels and risk for toxicity; slower titration and decreased dose of lamotrigine is recommended if both medications are prescribed.
  • Estrogen-containing contraceptives increase valproate clearance, decreasing serum valproate levels.

Adverse effects



Common adverse effects involve the gastrointestinal system (eg, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) and the CNS (eg, sedation, ataxia, tremor).  Weight gain is common with long-term treatment, likely due to valproate's role in insulin resistance.  Alopecia occurs in 5%-10% of patients treated with valproate.



Valproate has been associated with hyperandrogenism in women and may increase the risk for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).



Rare but serious complications may occur with valproate use, including:



  • Hepatotoxicity (most commonly in the first 6 months of treatment)
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Hyperammonemic encephalopathy (propionic acid, a metabolite of valproate, inhibits ammonia elimination in the urea cycle)


Valproate is contraindicated in patients at increased risk for these complications (eg, liver failure, urea cycle disorders).

Overdose



Lower levels of valproate toxicity result in mild-to-moderate lethargy, and recovery typically occurs without complications.



Severe toxicity of valproate may result in the following:



  • Vital sign abnormalities (hyperthermia, hypotension, tachycardia)
  • Hyperammonemia (may be asymptomatic or result in encephalopathy)
  • Hepatoxicity
  • Anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypernatremia, hypocalcemia
  • Tremors, myoclonus


Management includes obtaining history about timing, dose, and preparation of ingested valproate.  Collect serum valproate levels serially (initially and every 2-3 hours) when an acute overdose is suspected as peak levels may not occur for several hours, especially if a delayed-release preparation is involved.  Routine evaluation also includes fingerstick glucose, serum levels of possible coingestants (eg, acetaminophen, salicylate), and ECG.



For more severe cases, additional work-up involves electrolyte levels (eg, sodium, bicarbonate, calcium), plasma ammonia concentration, platelet level, and liver function testing.

Pregnancy considerations



Valproate has dose-dependent teratogenic risks.  Taking valproate during the first trimester (especially weeks 3-8, a critical period for organogenesis) is associated with an increased risk of:



  • Neural tube defects (eg, myelomeningocele) due to interference with folate metabolism (
    figure 3
    )
  • Craniofacial abnormalities (eg, cleft lip/palate)
  • Urogenital (eg, hypospadias) and cardiovascular malformations


In utero exposure to valproate is also associated with increased risk for cognitive deficiencies, autism spectrum disorder, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.  Therefore, patients should avoid valproate during pregnancy unless other treatment options are unacceptable (eg, inadequate symptom control).



If a patient taking valproate becomes or plans to become pregnant, carefully discuss and assess the benefits (eg, ongoing mood stability) and risks (eg, negative fetal outcomes).  Consider switching to a different mood stabilizer with less teratogenic potential (eg, lithium).  If valproate is continued, daily high-dose folic acid supplementation (4 mg) is recommended.

Monitoring



Obtain laboratory studies at baseline and routinely throughout valproate treatment to monitor for potential adverse effects:



  • Serum valproate levels to determine if dosing is within therapeutic range (50-125 mcg/mL) and to monitor for toxicity
  • Liver function tests (LFTs) to monitor for hepatotoxicity
  • Complete blood count to monitor platelet count for thrombocytopenia


When clinically indicated, obtaining the following can evaluate other potential adverse effects:



  • Ammonia levels to assess for hyperammonemic encephalopathy
  • Lipase/amylase to assess for acute pancreatitis
  • PT/PTT prior to surgery to assess for coagulopathy

Carbamazepine

Indications



Carbamazepine is used to treat acute mania or hypomania in bipolar disorder.  It can also be used to treat seizures and trigeminal neuralgia.

Pharmacology



Carbamazepine inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels, decreasing neuronal excitability (

figure 1
).



Carbamazepine is primarily metabolized through CYP3A4 and induces its own metabolism by upregulating the transcription of certain enzymes.  Stabilization of serum levels typically occurs 2-4 weeks after initiation.  Monitor serum levels after steady state is reached (ie, 5 days) and a few weeks later to assess for autoinduction effects and if dosing adjustment is needed.

Drug-drug interactions



Carbamazepine significantly induces many CYP450 enzymes, especially CYP3A4:



  • Increases clearance of oral contraceptives, decreasing serum levels and efficacy, which could result in unplanned pregnancy
  • Increases valproate clearance, decreasing serum valproate levels

Teratogenicity



Similar to valproate, carbamazepine is associated with fetal neural tube defects (eg, myelomeningocele) as well as cardiovascular and craniofacial malformations.  Avoid carbamazepine in pregnancy and in women of reproductive age when possible; daily high-dose folic acid supplementation is recommended if taking carbamazepine.

Adverse effects



Common adverse effects include somnolence, nausea, diarrhea, and rash.  Vitamin D deficiency may occur as carbamazepine induces an enzyme that breaks down vitamin D into its inactive metabolites.



Serious but rare adverse effects can occur, including:



  • Blood dyscrasias due to bone marrow suppression; onset typically within first 3-4 months of treatment.  May result in various conditions (eg, agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia), some of which are reversible with discontinuation of carbamazepine.
  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)
  • Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS), a potentially life-threatening condition that typically presents as a polymorphic rash with visceral organ involvement (eg, hepatotoxicity) developing within 2-8 weeks of treatment; discontinue carbamazepine if this syndrome occurs.
  • Hepatotoxicity (eg, serum aminotransferase elevations, hepatocellular jaundice), which may be reversible with discontinuation of carbamazepine
  • Hyponatremia, a dose-dependent risk of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)

Overdose



Symptoms of carbamazepine toxicity can include:



  • Drowsiness/lethargy
  • Anticholinergic effects (eg, hyperthermia, flushed skin, mydriasis)
  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Dysrhythmias


Evaluation includes obtaining history about timing, dose, and preparation of ingested carbamazepine.  Collect serum carbamazepine levels serially (since peak levels may not occur for a few days) until a downward trend is established.  Routine evaluation also includes fingerstick glucose and serum levels of possible coingestants (eg, acetaminophen, salicylate).



Management is primarily supportive (eg, airway protection, intravenous fluids).



For more severe cases, continuous cardiac monitoring may be necessary due to sodium channel blockade and risk for QRS prolongation and dysrhythmias; treatment includes sodium bicarbonate.

Monitoring



Obtain laboratory studies at baseline and routinely throughout carbamazepine treatment to monitor for potential adverse effects:



  • Serum carbamazepine levels to monitor for toxicity, especially if change in medication regimen that could affect drug metabolism
  • Complete blood count to monitor for blood dyscrasias (eg, anemia, agranulocytosis, pancytopenia)
  • Basic metabolic panel (BMP) to monitor for hyponatremia
  • LFTs to assess for hepatotoxicity


Before initiation of carbamazepine in patients of Asian ancestry, genetic screening for the HLA-B*1502 allele is recommended.  Carbamazepine should be avoided in those with this allele due to increased risk for SJS and TEN.

Lamotrigine

Indications



Lamotrigine is used for maintenance treatment in bipolar disorder to prevent further mood episodes.  It can treat acute bipolar depression but is not indicated for treating acute mania.  Lamotrigine is also used to treat seizures.

Pharmacology



Lamotrigine blocks voltage-gated sodium channels and reduces glutamate release, inhibiting neuronal excitation (

).

Drug-drug interactions



  • Estrogen-containing oral contraceptives can increase lamotrigine clearance, resulting in decreased lamotrigine levels; during use of hormone-free pills ("pill-free" week), serum levels of lamotrigine may increase.
  • Carbamazepine can also increase lamotrigine clearance and reduce lamotrigine levels; higher dosing may be necessary.
  • Valproate inhibits lamotrigine metabolism and increases risk for lamotrigine toxicity; slower titration and decreased dosing is recommended.

Adverse effects



Adverse effects are generally mild.  Most common effects include nausea, dizziness, fatigue, and insomnia.



A self-limited, benign rash can occur in up to 10% of those treated, which typically develops within the first 2 months of therapy.



A rare, life-threatening mucocutaneous reaction (ie, SJS, TEN) can occur in approximately 0.1% of patients.  Due to the difficulty in differentiating between a benign and life-threatening rash, discontinue lamotrigine at the first sign of any rash.  The risk of rash is elevated in children, coadministration with valproate, and rapid dose escalation.  Patients who suddenly stop lamotrigine should restart at the initial starting dose and undergo titration rather than resuming the existing dose.



Lamotrigine is also rarely associated with DRESS syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition that typically presents as a polymorphic rash with visceral organ involvement (eg, hepatotoxicity) and develops within 2-8 weeks of treatment.  Discontinue lamotrigine if this occurs.

Pregnancy considerations



Lamotrigine is relatively safe to use during pregnancy.  It does not appear to affect fetal neurocognitive development but may slightly increase the risk of cleft lip and/or cleft palate with use during the first trimester of pregnancy.

Overdose



Mild-to-moderate lamotrigine overdoses are generally benign and self-limited.  Severe overdoses can have life-threatening effects, such as seizures, arrhythmias, and coma.

Monitoring



Prior to starting lamotrigine, collect baseline laboratory studies (LFTs, BMP, complete blood count).  Routine laboratory studies are not indicated throughout treatment unless changes in clinical status occur.  Serum lamotrigine levels are not necessary, as dosing is based on clinical response.

Summary



Valproate, carbamazepine, and lamotrigine are anticonvulsants that can be used to treat specific phases of bipolar disorder (

).  Valproate is indicated for acute mania and maintenance treatment.  Carbamazepine can also treat acute mania, although it has the potential for significant drug-drug interactions.  Valproate and carbamazepine are teratogens and can cause major fetal malformations.  Lamotrigine has a relatively benign safety profile and is indicated for acute bipolar depression and maintenance treatment to prevent further mood episodes.
